The aroma of roasted garlic and fresh thyme drifted through the narrow streets of downtown Blacksburg as Cornelius Ashworth made his way home from the farmer's market, his canvas bag heavy with autumn vegetables and herbs. Most people wouldn't think twice about a young man in his late twenties carefully selecting the perfect butternut squash or examining bunches of sage with the intensity of a scholar, but then again, most people didn't know that Cornelius was a warlock whose magical abilities were intrinsically tied to the culinary arts.

The late October air carried hints of woodsmoke and dying leaves, and Cornelius pulled his wool coat tighter as he climbed the steps to his modest Victorian house on Clay Street. The house had belonged to his grandmother, a kitchen witch of considerable renown in certain circles, and when she passed five years ago, she left him not only the property but also her extensive collection of grimoires focused on gastronomic magic. What had started as a necessity to understand his inheritance had blossomed into a genuine passion that consumed most of his waking hours.

Inside, Cornelius set his purchases on the granite countertop of his meticulously organized kitchen. Copper pots hung from wrought iron hooks, while shelves lined with mason jars containing everything from dried lavender to crystallized ginger created a rainbow of ingredients along the walls. This was his sanctuary, his laboratory, and his temple all rolled into one. Here, he could transform simple ingredients into something approaching the divine, and if those transformations happened to be infused with protective charms or healing properties, well, that was simply an added benefit.

He had just begun unpacking when his phone buzzed with a text from his friend Maya, who worked at the university's folklore department and was one of the few people who knew about his unusual abilities. The message was brief but concerning: "Strange incidents around campus. People getting violently ill after eating at different restaurants. Doctors can't find anything wrong. Thought you should know."

Cornelius frowned, setting down a bunch of carrots. In his experience, when medical professionals couldn't identify the cause of an illness, it often meant the problem wasn't entirely natural. He had encountered cursed food before, usually the result of someone with more malice than skill attempting to use kitchen magic for harmful purposes. The results were typically messy but not particularly dangerous to anyone with proper training.

This felt different, though. The fact that multiple establishments were affected suggested either a coordinated effort or someone with significantly more power than the usual amateur practitioners who occasionally caused trouble. Cornelius made a mental note to do some investigating after dinner, which reminded him that he still needed to prepare his evening meal.

Cooking, for Cornelius, was both sustenance and meditation. Tonight he decided on a simple risotto with the butternut squash he'd selected so carefully, along with some pancetta from his favorite local butcher and a bottle of white wine that had been aging in his cellar. As he diced shallots with practiced precision, he let his mind wander to the problem Maya had presented.

The kitchen began to fill with the gentle sizzling of aromatics hitting hot olive oil, and Cornelius felt the familiar tingle of magic responding to his emotions and intentions. His grandmother had always told him that the key to successful culinary magic wasn't in elaborate rituals or exotic ingredients, but in the love and attention paid to each step of the process. "Cook with your heart," she used to say, "and the magic will follow naturally."

As he stirred the rice, gradually adding warm stock one ladle at a time, Cornelius found himself thinking about the delicate balance required for his particular brand of magic. Unlike other magical disciplines that relied on force of will or complex incantations, culinary magic demanded patience, timing, and an intuitive understanding of how different elements worked together. It was collaborative rather than commanding, persuasive rather than domineering.

The risotto was nearly finished when Cornelius felt it—a cold prickle at the base of his skull that made him pause mid-stir. Someone was watching him. Not physically present, but observing through magical means. The sensation was unfamiliar and decidedly unpleasant, like the feeling of waking up to find a stranger standing in your bedroom.

He continued cooking, trying to appear oblivious while extending his senses as carefully as possible. Whoever was scrying on him possessed considerable power, enough that a direct confrontation through magical channels would likely alert them to his awareness. Instead, Cornelius began weaving a subtle ward into his cooking, channeling protective energy through the gentle motions of stirring and seasoning.

The intrusion lasted only a few more minutes before withdrawing abruptly, leaving Cornelius with the distinct impression that he had been evaluated and found... interesting. Not threatening, which was probably for the best, but worth watching. He finished his risotto with hands that trembled only slightly, though whether from fear or excitement, he couldn't quite say.

After dinner, Cornelius walked the few blocks to campus, ostensibly for his evening constitutional but actually to investigate the sites Maya had mentioned. Virginia Tech's campus was beautiful in the autumn, with its Gothic Revival architecture framed by trees in brilliant reds and golds, but tonight it felt different. There was an undercurrent of unease that seemed to follow him as he made his way past the various dining establishments that dotted the area around campus.

At Giuseppe's, the Italian restaurant where the first incidents had occurred, Cornelius lingered outside long enough to catch traces of residual magical energy clinging to the building like smoke. The signature was unfamiliar but unmistakably hostile, with an underlying current of something that felt almost gleeful in its malevolence. This wasn't someone who had turned to dark magic out of desperation or ignorance; this was someone who genuinely enjoyed causing suffering.

The realization sent a chill down Cornelius's spine that had nothing to do with the October evening. In his five years of practicing magic, he had encountered practitioners who were careless, misguided, or simply incompetent, but never anyone who seemed to take active pleasure in causing harm. This suggested a level of corruption that went far beyond simple malicious mischief.The magical residue at the other affected establishments told a similar story, each location marked by that same malevolent signature but with subtle variations that suggested the perpetrator was experimenting, refining their technique with each attempt. Cornelius found himself particularly disturbed by the traces he detected outside the campus coffee shop where several students had been hospitalized. The energy there felt almost playful, as if whoever was responsible had been amusing themselves by targeting young people who had no understanding of what was happening to them.

By the time he returned home, Cornelius had reached the uncomfortable conclusion that Blacksburg was dealing with a practitioner of considerable skill and absolutely no conscience. The fact that they had been bold enough to scry on him directly suggested either supreme confidence or dangerous recklessness, neither of which boded well for the situation's resolution. He made himself a cup of chamomile tea infused with subtle calming enchantments and settled into his grandmother's old rocking chair to think through his options.

The rational approach would be to contact the Council of Practitioners, the loose confederation of magical users who occasionally coordinated responses to threats that affected the broader community. They had resources he lacked and experience dealing with rogue practitioners who had crossed the line from mischief into genuine malevolence. The problem was that the Council moved slowly, preferring lengthy deliberations and careful consensus-building to rapid action, and in the meantime, more innocent people would likely fall victim to whatever twisted experiments were being conducted.

Cornelius sipped his tea and considered the alternative: taking direct action himself. His grandmother had been respected in the magical community not just for her knowledge but for her willingness to intervene when others preferred to avoid unpleasantness. She had never hesitated to use her abilities to protect people, whether they knew they needed protection or not. The more he thought about it, the more convinced he became that she would expect him to follow her example, regardless of the personal risk involved.

The next morning brought unseasonably warm weather and troubling news. Maya called while Cornelius was preparing his breakfast, her voice tight with worry as she reported that three more students had been hospitalized overnight after eating at completely different establishments. The pattern was becoming impossible to ignore, and rumors were beginning to spread around campus about everything from food poisoning to bioterrorism. The university administration was struggling to maintain calm while health officials scrambled to find explanations that would satisfy both the media and increasingly anxious parents.

"The weirdest part," Maya continued, "is that the victims all report the same thing before they collapse. They say the food tasted absolutely incredible, better than anything they'd ever eaten before, and then within an hour they're in agony. The doctors are calling it psychosomatic, but I've seen three of them myself, and there's nothing psychological about their condition."

Cornelius felt his blood run cold as the implications of Maya's words sank in. Using magic to enhance flavor was one of the most basic techniques in culinary enchantment, something his grandmother had taught him when he was barely old enough to reach the stovetop safely. But weaponizing that enhancement, turning pleasure into pain through magical manipulation, required a level of sophistication and cruelty that spoke to years of dedicated study and practice. This wasn't some amateur who had stumbled across a few spells in an old book; this was someone who understood the deeper principles of gastronomic magic and had deliberately perverted them.

After ending the call with Maya, Cornelius spent the morning researching everything he could find about malevolent applications of culinary magic. His grandmother's library was extensive, but she had been fundamentally a healer and protector, more interested in nurturing than harming. The few references he found to darker practices were brief and disapproving, clearly included more for completeness than practical application. What emerged from his reading was a disturbing picture of magic that worked by creating dependency and addiction before turning that craving into a source of suffering.

The afternoon brought another piece of the puzzle when Cornelius received an unexpected visitor. He was in his garden, harvesting the last of his autumn herbs before the first frost, when he became aware of someone standing at his back gate. The woman was perhaps sixty, well-dressed in the understated way that suggested real money rather than pretension, with silver hair pulled back in an elegant chignon and intelligent gray eyes that seemed to take in every detail of his carefully tended plants.

"Mr. Ashworth?" Her voice carried the faint trace of an accent he couldn't quite place, cultured and precise. "I wonder if I might have a word with you. I believe we have a mutual concern regarding recent events in the area."

Cornelius straightened slowly, his hands still full of rosemary and sage, trying to read the woman's intentions through the subtle magical cues he had learned to trust. She radiated power in a way that immediately put him on guard, but there was nothing hostile in her presence. Instead, he sensed the careful control of someone accustomed to wielding considerable authority and the underlying tension of genuine worry poorly concealed beneath a composed exterior.

"I'm afraid you have me at a disadvantage," he replied carefully, making no move to approach the gate. "You seem to know who I am, but I can't say the same."

The woman smiled, though it didn't entirely reach her eyes. "My name is Eleanor Blackthorne, and I represent certain interests that have become concerned about the situation developing around the university. I understand that you've been investigating the recent incidents of mysterious illness, and I believe it would be beneficial for us to share information."Cornelius studied Eleanor Blackthorne for a long moment, weighing his options. Her name was vaguely familiar, though he couldn't quite place where he might have heard it before. There was something about her presence that suggested connections to the wider magical community, the kind of institutional knowledge and authority that came from years of involvement in matters that ordinary practitioners never encountered. The careful way she had approached him, appearing at his back gate rather than his front door, suggested both respect for his privacy and an understanding of the need for discretion that amateur practitioners rarely possessed.

"I suppose we should talk inside," he said finally, moving toward the gate with measured steps. "Though I should warn you that I prefer direct conversation to elaborate games of information trading. If you know something about what's been happening, I'd rather hear it plainly than spend the afternoon dancing around implications and possibilities."

Eleanor's smile became more genuine as she followed him through the garden toward his back door. "I appreciate directness, Mr. Ashworth, particularly in circumstances as serious as these. What I can tell you is that the practitioner responsible for these attacks is someone we've been tracking for several years, though they've proven remarkably skilled at avoiding direct confrontation. Your recent investigation has finally given us an opportunity to make contact with someone who has encountered their work firsthand, which is why I'm here."

The kitchen felt smaller with Eleanor Blackthorne's presence filling it, though she moved through the space with the careful appreciation of someone who understood its true purpose. Her eyes lingered on the carefully organized herbs, the well-seasoned cast iron pans, and the subtle protective charms woven into the room's very structure. Cornelius found himself oddly pleased by her obvious recognition of the thought and skill that had gone into creating his workspace, even as he remained wary of her ultimate intentions.

"Before we go any further," he said, filling the kettle and setting it on the stove, "I think you should tell me exactly who 'we' represents and why you've been tracking someone for years without doing anything to stop them. Because from where I'm standing, it looks like whoever is doing this has been allowed to hurt innocent people while bureaucrats debated the proper response."

Eleanor settled into one of the wooden chairs at his kitchen table, her posture remaining perfectly composed despite the edge in his voice. "The organization I represent doesn't have an official name, though some refer to us as the Archive. We specialize in tracking and documenting practitioners who have crossed certain lines, particularly those whose activities threaten to expose the magical community to unwanted scrutiny. As for why we haven't stopped this individual, I'm afraid the answer is more complicated than simple bureaucratic inaction."

She paused as Cornelius prepared tea, her attention focused on his movements with the intensity of someone who understood the subtle magical currents that flowed through even the most mundane domestic tasks. "The practitioner we're dealing with goes by the name Morrigan Ashcroft, though we suspect that's an adopted identity rather than their birth name. They possess extraordinary skill in several branches of magic, but their particular expertise lies in what you might call psychological manipulation through sensory experience. Food is simply their preferred medium, though they've been known to work through other channels when it suits their purposes."

The kettle's whistle provided a brief interruption, during which Cornelius processed this information while preparing their tea. The name Morrigan Ashcroft meant nothing to him, but the description of their abilities sent a chill of recognition through him. He had encountered traces of that same manipulative energy at every site he had investigated, the sense of someone who took genuine pleasure in the process of turning comfort into torment, nourishment into suffering.

"What makes this situation particularly dangerous," Eleanor continued as she accepted her cup, "is that Ashcroft doesn't simply attack randomly. They study their targets carefully, learning their preferences and vulnerabilities before striking. The attacks we've been seeing here in Blacksburg represent a significant escalation in both scope and boldness, which suggests they may be building toward something much more ambitious than isolated incidents of magical assault."

Cornelius sat across from her, his own tea forgotten as the implications of her words sank in. "You're saying that the students who have been hospitalized are just preliminary tests for something worse. That whoever this Ashcroft person is, they're using Blacksburg as some kind of experimental laboratory while they perfect their technique."

"That's exactly what I'm saying," Eleanor replied grimly. "And based on patterns we've observed in other locations where Ashcroft has operated, I believe they're preparing for what we might call a mass casualty event. Something designed not just to cause suffering but to create widespread panic and potentially expose the existence of magical practitioners to public scrutiny on a scale that would be impossible to contain or explain away."

The afternoon light streaming through his kitchen windows suddenly seemed less warm, and Cornelius found himself thinking about all the innocent people going about their daily lives, completely unaware that they were being stalked by someone with the power and inclination to transform their next meal into an instrument of torture. The responsibility of that knowledge settled on his shoulders like a physical weight, bringing with it the uncomfortable realization that his quiet life of culinary experimentation and scholarly research was about to become considerably more complicated.

"So what exactly are you asking of me?" he said finally. "Because I'm beginning to suspect that this conversation isn't just about sharing information. You want something specific, and I'd rather know what it is before I commit to anything that might get me killed or worse."

Eleanor's expression grew more serious, and for the first time since her arrival, Cornelius caught a glimpse of the genuine worry she had been working so hard to conceal. "What we're asking is for your help in drawing Ashcroft out into the open where we can deal with them directly. Your investigation has already attracted their attention, which means you're in a unique position to make contact in a way that our more official representatives cannot. The fact that they bothered to scry on you yesterday suggests they view you as either a potential threat or a possible ally, either of which could work to our advantage."

The casual mention of yesterday's magical surveillance confirmed what Cornelius had already suspected about Eleanor Blackthorne's resources and connections. She clearly had access to information gathering capabilities that went far beyond anything a private practitioner could manage, which raised uncomfortable questions about exactly how long he had been under observation and by whom. The realization that his activities had been monitored without his knowledge left him feeling exposed and manipulated, emotions that he struggled to keep from showing on his face.

"And what happens to me when this Ashcroft person realizes I'm working with you?" he asked. "Because something tells me that people who torture innocent students for experimental data aren't likely to respond well to direct opposition, particularly from someone whose magical abilities are focused on healing rather than combat."

Eleanor leaned forward slightly, her gray eyes holding his with an intensity that spoke to years of experience in convincing reluctant individuals to take necessary risks. "We wouldn't ask you to face Ashcroft alone or without protection. The Archive has resources that can shield you from most forms of magical attack, and we would ensure that backup was available should the situation turn dangerous. What we need from you is simply the opportunity to make contact, to draw them into a confrontation on terms that favor us rather than allowing them to continue operating from the shadows."

The kitchen fell silent except for the soft ticking of his grandmother's old clock and the distant sound of students walking past on Clay Street, heading home from afternoon classes with no idea that their evening meals might be weapons in a magical war they couldn't even imagine. Cornelius found himself thinking about his grandmother, wondering what she would have done in similar circumstances. She had always been fiercely protective of innocent people, willing to take personal risks to prevent harm even when it would have been easier to look the other way.

"I need to know more about what you're really asking me to do," he said finally. "Because 'making contact' could mean anything from sending a message to walking into what amounts to a magical ambush, and I'm not foolish enough to agree to something without understanding the specifics. If you want my help, I need details, not euphemisms and vague assurances about protection that may or may not actually materialize when I need it most."

Eleanor nodded approvingly, as if his caution confirmed something positive about his character rather than indicating reluctance to cooperate. "The plan we have in mind is relatively straightforward, though admittedly not without risk. We want you to continue your investigation, but more openly this time, making it clear that you're actively working to identify and stop whoever is responsible for the attacks. This should provoke Ashcroft into direct contact, either to eliminate you as a threat or to attempt to recruit you as an ally."

She reached into her purse and withdrew a small silver pendant on a delicate chain, setting it on the table between them. "This will provide both protection and communication. It's keyed to respond to hostile magical activity directed against you personally, and it will allow our response team to locate and reach you within minutes of activation. More importantly, it will record everything that happens during any magical encounters, ensuring that we have the information we need to track Ashcroft even if the initial confrontation doesn't go as planned."

Cornelius picked up the pendant, feeling the subtle thrum of contained power that marked sophisticated magical craftsmanship. The silver was warm to the touch despite having been in Eleanor's purse, and he could sense layers of protective enchantment woven into its structure with a skill that exceeded anything in his grandmother's collection. Whatever organization Eleanor represented, they clearly had access to resources and expertise that placed them far above the level of typical magical practitioners.

"How do I know this isn't some kind of elaborate setup?" he asked, though he was already beginning to suspect that he would agree to her request regardless of his reservations. "For all I know, you could be working with this Ashcroft person, using me as bait to flush out other practitioners who might oppose whatever they're planning. The timing of your appearance is awfully convenient, showing up just when I've started investigating seriously."

Eleanor's expression grew almost amused, though there was no mockery in her smile. "Mr. Ashworth, if we wanted to harm you or use you as unwilling bait, there would be no need for elaborate deceptions. Your magical abilities, while admirable in their own sphere, are hardly sufficient to prevent more direct approaches should we have hostile intentions. The fact that I'm sitting in your kitchen asking for cooperation rather than compelling it should tell you something about both our methods and our genuine respect for your autonomy."

The logic was sound, if somewhat insulting, and Cornelius found himself reluctantly convinced that Eleanor Blackthorne's motivations were probably genuine. The alternative explanations for her presence required levels of complexity and resource investment that seemed disproportionate to any benefit that could be gained from manipulating a relatively minor culinary magic practitioner. More importantly, the pendant in his hand radiated the kind of benevolent protective energy that would be difficult to fake convincingly, particularly for someone with his sensitivity to magical emanations.

"All right," he said, slipping the chain over his head and feeling the pendant settle against his chest with a warmth that spoke of activation and acceptance. "I'll help you draw out this Ashcroft person, but I want regular communication and immediate extraction if the situation becomes more dangerous than anticipated. And I want your word that if this goes badly, the Archive or whatever you call yourselves will take responsibility for protecting any innocent people who get caught in the crossfire."

Eleanor stood, extending her hand in a gesture that managed to convey both gratitude and the sealing of a formal agreement. "You have my word, Mr. Ashworth, and more importantly, you have the Archive's commitment to seeing this matter resolved with minimal harm to uninvolved parties. We'll be monitoring the situation closely, and at the first sign of escalation beyond your ability to handle safely, we'll intervene directly."

After Eleanor left, Cornelius spent the evening researching everything he could find about magical surveillance and protection, trying to prepare himself for what was likely to be the most dangerous undertaking of his life. The pendant around his neck provided a constant reminder of his new responsibilities, its gentle warmth both reassuring and ominous as he contemplated the reality of deliberately attracting the attention of someone who had already demonstrated a willingness to torture innocent people for experimental purposes.

As night fell over Blacksburg, Cornelius made himself a simple dinner of pasta with herbs from his garden, infusing the meal with subtle strengthening charms and protective enchantments that he hoped would provide some additional defense against whatever magical attacks might be coming his way. The familiar rituals of cooking helped calm his nerves somewhat, though he couldn't shake the feeling that he was preparing for a battle using tools designed for healing and nourishment rather than warfare.

The next morning would mark the beginning of his new role as bait in a trap designed to catch a predator who had already proven both clever and ruthless. As Cornelius settled into his grandmother's rocking chair with a cup of chamomile tea, he found himself hoping that Eleanor Blackthorne's confidence in the Archive's protective capabilities was justified, because he was about to discover just how far someone would go to defend innocent people from magical predators who viewed human suffering as nothing more than an entertaining experiment.**Chapter 2**

The following morning brought an unseasonable chill that seemed to settle into Cornelius's bones despite the protective warmth radiating from Eleanor's pendant. He had spent a restless night plagued by dreams of shadowy figures moving through his kitchen, contaminating his carefully prepared meals with malevolent intentions that transformed nourishment into torture. The dreams had been vivid enough that he found himself checking and rechecking his herb jars and spice containers, as if Morrigan Ashcroft might have somehow infiltrated his sanctuary during the dark hours before dawn.

Maya arrived at his back door just after eight o'clock, her usually cheerful demeanor replaced by the kind of grim determination that spoke to sleepless nights and growing worry. She carried a leather messenger bag that appeared to be stuffed with papers and printouts, and her first words confirmed Cornelius's suspicion that the situation on campus had deteriorated significantly overnight. The university administration was struggling to maintain any semblance of normalcy as reports of mysterious illnesses continued to spread, and the local health department was beginning to ask questions that would be difficult to answer without revealing the supernatural elements at play.

"Three more students were hospitalized last night," Maya said without preamble, accepting the cup of coffee Cornelius offered with hands that trembled slightly from either caffeine withdrawal or stress. "But here's the really disturbing part – they didn't eat at any restaurants. Two of them were in their dorm rooms eating food they had prepared themselves, and the third was at a house party where dozens of other people ate the same dishes without any problems. Whatever is causing this is becoming more targeted and more sophisticated."

Cornelius felt the pendant against his chest grow slightly warmer as Maya spoke, responding to his elevated emotional state with the subtle adjustment that marked truly sophisticated magical craftsmanship. The implications of her report were deeply troubling, suggesting that Morrigan Ashcroft had moved beyond the experimental phase of their campaign and was now demonstrating the ability to strike at specific individuals regardless of their precautions or location. The level of magical skill required for such targeted attacks was far beyond what most practitioners could achieve, even with years of dedicated study and practice.

"Did the victims report the same thing as before?" he asked, though he suspected he already knew the answer. "The food tasting extraordinary followed by rapid onset of symptoms that the doctors can't explain or treat effectively?"

Maya nodded grimly, pulling a stack of printouts from her bag and spreading them across his kitchen table. "All three described their last meal as the most delicious thing they had ever tasted, even though we're talking about basic dorm food and typical college party snacks. One of them actually used the word 'transcendent' to describe a microwave burrito, which should tell you something about how far removed from normal reality this has become. The medical staff is starting to use terms like 'mass hysteria' and 'psychological contagion,' but I've seen these kids, Cornelius. Whatever is happening to them is absolutely physical."

The documents Maya had brought contained detailed reports from the university health center, copies of statements from the affected students, and what appeared to be her own analysis of the temporal and geographical patterns underlying the attacks. Cornelius was impressed despite his growing concern by the thoroughness of her investigation and the insight she had demonstrated in connecting seemingly random incidents. Her background in folklore studies had apparently given her a framework for recognizing supernatural patterns that medical professionals and law enforcement would dismiss as coincidence.

"Look at this," Maya said, pointing to a hand-drawn map of the campus and surrounding area marked with colored pins indicating the locations and times of each incident. "If you ignore the chronological sequence and focus on the geographical distribution, a pattern starts to emerge. The attacks aren't random – they're following specific pathways that connect significant locations around the university. It's almost like someone is using the campus itself as a component in a larger magical working."

Cornelius studied the map carefully, his understanding of magical theory allowing him to recognize the sophisticated geometric relationships that Maya had identified through pure intuition and careful observation. The affected locations formed a complex pattern that seemed to follow the natural flow of energy through the area, creating a network of connected points that could theoretically be used to amplify and focus magical power on a scale far beyond what any individual practitioner could achieve alone. The realization that Ashcroft was apparently constructing some kind of large-scale ritual framework using the students as unwilling components sent a chill of genuine fear through him.

"This is worse than I thought," he said quietly, tracing the connections between incidents with his finger. "What you've identified here isn't just a pattern of attacks – it's the preliminary phase of a major magical working that will use the entire campus as a focus and amplifier. If I'm reading this correctly, every person who has been affected so far is now connected to Ashcroft through magical bonds that can be activated and manipulated at will. We're not dealing with isolated incidents of malicious magic; we're looking at the construction of a supernatural weapon that could affect thousands of people simultaneously."

Maya's face paled as the implications of his analysis sank in, and she began gathering the papers with the frantic energy of someone who has suddenly realized the true scope of a threat they had been systematically underestimating. Her folklore background had given her the tools to recognize supernatural patterns, but she lacked the magical training necessary to understand their full significance until Cornelius provided the context that transformed disturbing coincidences into the components of a terrifying larger design. The knowledge that they were facing something far more dangerous than simple malicious mischief seemed to energize rather than paralyze her, confirming Cornelius's impression that his friend possessed the kind of courage that would be essential in the confrontation that was rapidly approaching.

"What do we do?" she asked, her voice steady despite the fear in her eyes. "Because I'm assuming that you have some kind of plan beyond hoping that whoever is responsible gets bored and moves on to terrorize people somewhere else. This is my university, these are my students and colleagues, and I'm not about to stand by and watch while some magical psychopath turns them into components in whatever twisted experiment they're conducting."

Before Cornelius could respond, the pendant around his neck began to pulse with a rhythm that spoke of immediate danger approaching from an unexpected direction. The protective enchantments Eleanor had woven into the silver were responding to hostile magical activity in the immediate vicinity, which meant that their conversation had either been overheard by unfriendly listeners or that their investigation had triggered some kind of supernatural alarm system. Either possibility suggested that Morrigan Ashcroft's surveillance capabilities were far more sophisticated than anyone had anticipated, and that their window for taking action was closing more rapidly than expected.

"Maya," he said quietly, his voice carrying the kind of controlled urgency that made her freeze in the middle of organizing her papers, "I need you to gather everything up and move very slowly toward the back door. Don't look around, don't ask questions, and don't do anything that might seem like preparation for flight or fight. Someone is watching us right now, and I suspect we're about to receive a visit from the person responsible for everything we've been discussing."

The temperature in the kitchen began to drop noticeably despite the morning sunshine streaming through the windows, and Cornelius felt the familiar prickle of hostile magical energy that he had first encountered during yesterday's scrying attempt. This time, however, the sensation was far stronger and more focused, suggesting that Ashcroft had decided to abandon subtlety in favor of direct confrontation. The pendant against his chest grew warm enough to be noticeable through his shirt, its protective enchantments responding to the increasing level of supernatural threat with automatic adjustments that spoke to Eleanor's expertise in crafting defensive magical items.

Maya moved toward the back door with admirable calm, though Cornelius could see the tension in her shoulders and the careful way she avoided sudden movements that might trigger whatever predatory instincts were currently focused on them. Her folklore training had apparently included enough exposure to supernatural dangers to provide some understanding of how to behave when caught in potentially lethal situations, though he doubted that academic preparation could fully prepare anyone for the reality of facing a practitioner who had demonstrated both significant power and complete disregard for human suffering.

The hostile presence seemed to hesitate at the threshold of his property, as if encountering some kind of barrier or ward that required careful analysis before proceeding. Cornelius felt a moment of gratitude for his grandmother's foresight in protecting the house with layers of defensive magic that had been maintained and strengthened over decades of careful attention. The protections wouldn't stop a determined assault by someone of Ashcroft's apparent capabilities, but they might provide enough delay and warning to allow escape or the arrival of Eleanor's promised backup support.

"Mr. Ashworth," a voice called from the front yard, cultured and pleasant in a way that made Cornelius's skin crawl with its absolute lack of genuine warmth or humanity. "I believe we have matters to discuss that would be better addressed in person rather than through intermediaries or surveillance. I'm sure you'll understand that recent developments have made it necessary for us to clarify our respective positions before any unfortunate misunderstandings lead to consequences that neither of us would prefer."

The voice belonged to someone who had clearly spent years perfecting the art of making threats sound like invitations, wrapping menace in layers of politeness that couldn't quite disguise the underlying predatory hunger. Cornelius had encountered similar speech patterns in his grandmother's stories about practitioners who had allowed their pursuit of power to corrupt their fundamental humanity, transforming them into something that wore human shape while pursuing goals that no longer had anything to do with human concerns or limitations.

Maya reached the back door and paused, her hand on the knob as she looked back at Cornelius with a question in her eyes. He nodded slightly, hoping that Eleanor's people were monitoring the situation and would intervene before things escalated beyond his ability to handle safely. The pendant's warmth suggested that help was at least aware of the developing situation, though whether that awareness would translate into timely assistance remained to be seen. Academic theories about magical protection were about to be tested against the reality of a practitioner who had demonstrated both considerable skill and complete willingness to use that skill against innocent people.

"I appreciate the invitation," Cornelius called back, surprised by how steady his own voice sounded despite the fear that was making his hands shake slightly. "Though I confess I'm curious about what kind of discussion you had in mind, given that your recent activities suggest a preference for monologue over genuine conversation. Perhaps we could start with an explanation of why you've been using local students as experimental subjects in whatever research project you're conducting."

The laugh that answered his question contained no trace of genuine humor, instead carrying the kind of delighted malice that spoke to someone who had found a new and interesting toy to play with before ultimately destroying it. Cornelius felt Maya tense beside the door as the sound washed over them, and he realized that whatever happened next would likely determine not only his own fate but the safety of everyone on the university campus who had become unwilling participants in Ashcroft's larger design. The time for investigation and preparation had ended; now came the moment when academic understanding of magical theory would be tested against the brutal reality of supernatural combat.

"Oh, Mr. Ashworth," the voice continued, moving closer to the house with footsteps that seemed to echo with more than ordinary sound, "I'm afraid you've misunderstood the nature of my work entirely. Those students weren't experimental subjects – they were ingredients in a recipe that required very specific preparation and seasoning. You see, I've been developing a new approach to large-scale magical working that utilizes the emotional and physical resonance created by transforming pleasure into pain, comfort into torment. The aroma of roasted garlic and fresh thyme drifted through the narrow streets of downtown Blacksburg as Cornelius Ashworth made his way home from the farmer's market, his canvas bag heavy with autumn vegetables and herbs. Most people wouldn't think twice about a young man in his late twenties carefully selecting the perfect butternut squash or examining bunches of sage with the intensity of a scholar, but then again, most people didn't know that Cornelius was a warlock whose magical abilities were intrinsically tied to the culinary arts.

The late October air carried hints of woodsmoke and dying leaves, and Cornelius pulled his wool coat tighter as he climbed the steps to his modest Victorian house on Clay Street. The house had belonged to his grandmother, a kitchen witch of considerable renown in certain circles, and when she passed five years ago, she left him not only the property but also her extensive collection of grimoires focused on gastronomic magic. What had started as a necessity to understand his inheritance had blossomed into a genuine passion that consumed most of his waking hours.

Inside, Cornelius set his purchases on the granite countertop of his meticulously organized kitchen. Copper pots hung from wrought iron hooks, while shelves lined with mason jars containing everything from dried lavender to crystallized ginger created a rainbow of ingredients along the walls. This was his sanctuary, his laboratory, and his temple all rolled into one. Here, he could transform simple ingredients into something approaching the divine, and if those transformations happened to be infused with protective charms or healing properties, well, that was simply an added benefit.

He had just begun unpacking when his phone buzzed with a text from his friend Maya, who worked at the university's folklore department and was one of the few people who knew about his unusual abilities. The message was brief but concerning: "Strange incidents around campus. People getting violently ill after eating at different restaurants. Doctors can't find anything wrong. Thought you should know."

Cornelius frowned, setting down a bunch of carrots. In his experience, when medical professionals couldn't identify the cause of an illness, it often meant the problem wasn't entirely natural. He had encountered cursed food before, usually the result of someone with more malice than skill attempting to use kitchen magic for harmful purposes. The results were typically messy but not particularly dangerous to anyone with proper training.

This felt different, though. The fact that multiple establishments were affected suggested either a coordinated effort or someone with significantly more power than the usual amateur practitioners who occasionally caused trouble. Cornelius made a mental note to do some investigating after dinner, which reminded him that he still needed to prepare his evening meal.

Cooking, for Cornelius, was both sustenance and meditation. Tonight he decided on a simple risotto with the butternut squash he'd selected so carefully, along with some pancetta from his favorite local butcher and a bottle of white wine that had been aging in his cellar. As he diced shallots with practiced precision, he let his mind wander to the problem Maya had presented.

The kitchen began to fill with the gentle sizzling of aromatics hitting hot olive oil, and Cornelius felt the familiar tingle of magic responding to his emotions and intentions. His grandmother had always told him that the key to successful culinary magic wasn't in elaborate rituals or exotic ingredients, but in the love and attention paid to each step of the process. "Cook with your heart," she used to say, "and the magic will follow naturally."

As he stirred the rice, gradually adding warm stock one ladle at a time, Cornelius found himself thinking about the delicate balance required for his particular brand of magic. Unlike other magical disciplines that relied on force of will or complex incantations, culinary magic demanded patience, timing, and an intuitive understanding of how different elements worked together. It was collaborative rather than commanding, persuasive rather than domineering.

The risotto was nearly finished when Cornelius felt it—a cold prickle at the base of his skull that made him pause mid-stir. Someone was watching him. Not physically present, but observing through magical means. The sensation was unfamiliar and decidedly unpleasant, like the feeling of waking up to find a stranger standing in your bedroom.

He continued cooking, trying to appear oblivious while extending his senses as carefully as possible. Whoever was scrying on him possessed considerable power, enough that a direct confrontation through magical channels would likely alert them to his awareness. Instead, Cornelius began weaving a subtle ward into his cooking, channeling protective energy through the gentle motions of stirring and seasoning.

The intrusion lasted only a few more minutes before withdrawing abruptly, leaving Cornelius with the distinct impression that he had been evaluated and found... interesting. Not threatening, which was probably for the best, but worth watching. He finished his risotto with hands that trembled only slightly, though whether from fear or excitement, he couldn't quite say.
